comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]  I love how flimsy the positioning brackets are. (obviously the real attachments are the many bolts not so clearly seen).

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: The chap in the middle is of course JJC Bradfield, chief engineer NSW Public Works Department, who was responsible for the initial bridge design. To the rhs is Lawrence Ennis, director of construction with the contractor Dorman Long & Co. Bradfield remains well known, but Ennis has been somewhat forgotten, which is a bit remiss given he was in effect in charge of day to day construction of the bridge. The SLNSW has some good pics of both Bradfield and Ennis...if anyone is interested, I've left links at this pic www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/7140519229/ ; we see Bradfield and Ennis in a few of these recently posted PHM collection pics - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283755426/in/pho... ; www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283760394/in/pho... ; www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283744212/in/pho... ; www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283769518/in/pho...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Good idea! But as I've had mixed results trying to get my new toaster to work, I'll leave the Ennis gallery to someone else! Here's a few of the Sam Hood pics of Ennis from the SLNSW collection - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=9175 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=9974 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=44256 (in this pic Ennis is out of focus in the background) ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=9180 (to the lhs of NSW Governor Sir Philip Game)

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: The 3rd gent in this pic (who I can't yet identify) looks a bit like the dapper chap seen in this other PHM collection pic - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283755242/ My initial theory/guess was that the dapper chap might be Ralph Freeman, who was consulting and design engineer to Dorman Long & Co. Freeman (and his team) were in effect responsible for the final bridge design...and like Ennis he's been largely forgotten...however I've had to concede that these SRNSW pics of Freeman tend to show my theory/guess up as a turkey investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/search.as... ...but on the up side, these SRNSW pics have enabled me to identify Freeman in this pic www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283755426/in/pho...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I think we also see the 3rd gent in this other PHM collection pic, which is evidently dated 3/5/1927...he's standing to the rhs of Ennis (ie the viewer's rhs)...he's wearing a different tie but the hat looks the same and again a handkerchief protrudes from his breast pocket... www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283769518/in/pho... ...and also in this pic, again to the rhs of Ennis - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283744212/in/pho... ; I'm now convinced that this 3rd gent is the dapper chap we see in this other PHM collection pic which was taken on 10/9/1930 at the top chord - www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=365368&... ; Maybe as further pics from the various Harbour Bridge collections are digitised, info re his identity will emerge...as things stand he appears to have been part of the action from at least 1927 thru until 1930. This 1932 SMH feature article includes a pics of both the Public Works Dept and Dorman Long bridge construction teams...it's difficult to tell given the resolution of the SMH pics...and in addition, several of the Dorman Long engineers were evidently absent...but the best match for the 'dapper chap' I can see is the bloke on the front lhs of the Dorman Long team sitting next to Freeman...per the caption he is C. Hipwell DL's supervisor of steelworks erection...but there's not enough resolution in the SMH pic to be at all firm on this...nla.gov.au/nla.news-page1157143 trove.nla.gov.au/work/168965247?q=nuc%3ANRTA+sydney+harbo... - Founded! ...this pic (which is also hidden away over at SRNSW investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/search.as... ) appears to be a reverse of the negative (ie. it's the wrong way around)...it's another of the pics taken on 10/9/1930 at the top chord...the day the northern and southern spans of the top chord were joined...the accompanying caption identifies Hipwell...though I'm not convinced the caption is correct re Ralph Freeman...I'd say it's Frank Litchfield...all up I'm about 98.4% convinced that Hipwell is the 'dapper chap' we see here from.ph/365368 ...still to establish his first name and bio info www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283763420/in/set... possibly another of the pics taken on 10/9/1930 at the top chord. I love this pic ...Here we see the brains trust who designed and supervised the construction of the bridge (or at least a few of them), side by side with the blokes who actually built it...and if my guess re the date/place is correct, this pic was taken at one of the most significant points in the construction, when the upper chord was joined and the arch was completed...arguably the most significant point in the construction had occurred a few weeks previously when the lower chord had been joined...I gather this pic shows the bridge workers with one of the hydraulic jacks which were brought into use at this juncture...when the two spans were being joined...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Per the acquisition note above, this latest batch of PHM Harbour Bridge pics was donated to the PHM by Dorothy Stuckey. I gather her husband might have been Gordon Stuckey, who was a NSW Works Department Harbour Bridge engineer...he's in the pic of suits taken at the top chord on 10/9/1930 (link above). These pics from Stuckey's collection are quite remarkable as they appear to include many of the principal figures involved in the design and construction of the bridge...not posing in a studio...but out there on and around the bridge during the various stages of construction. With a bit more research I'd say we could put a few more names to the various people who appear in the pics. This other pic www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283755426/ is a good example of just how significant these Stuckey pics are...it includes three of the principal figures involved in the bridge design and construction...Lawrence Ennis (director of construction with Dorman Long & Co, who was responsible for day to day construction), JJC Bradfield (who produced the initial bridge design, etc, etc) and Ralph Freeman (consulting engineer to Dorman Long & Co, who led the team of engineers...including Roberts and Pain...who produced the final bridge design).

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=389453 the March 1932 SMH pic of the Works Dept bridge team...zoom-in-able...with captions!

comment.author: 47201412@N02

comment.author: 24785917@N03
comment._content: Flickr version of www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=389453 image is coming online in the next few days.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: www.youtube.com/watch?v=JPQ7CzVHdMs - this video is fascinating...it includes priceless footage by Henri Mallard and wonderful commentary (dating from 1969) by former NSW Works Dept Harbour Bridge engineer Frank Litchfield, then aged 80 (I now realise Litchfield features in a number of the Harbour Bridge pics from the various collections)...the sound isn't too clear...but at ca. 33.10 Litchfield refers to Hipwell...if I hear correctly I think he says 'Mr Charles Hipwell'...however Peter Lalor's book "The Bridge" (2005) has his name as Clarence...there's a good pic of Litchfield here - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8078318330/
